I'd recommend people to not use their distro's stock python to deploy any python service though. Also much more here: https://docs.python.org/3/whatsnew/3.6.html

```
PEP 498, formatted string literals.
PEP 515, underscores in numeric literals.
PEP 526, syntax for variable annotations.
PEP 525, asynchronous generators.
PEP 530: asynchronous comprehensions.
```

It's still not supported. I think this would require a SIP (Superset Improvement Proposal). I don't think this would be too hard to do though. 

Essentially we need a new model "RowLevelSecurityFilter" that has a many-to-one relationship to "BaseDatasource", and many-to-one to "Roles". Then we need the CRUD to manage those (UI and REST API), FAB's ModelView can provide much of this for free.

After it's a matter of forcing the filter into the `query` method of each connector.

Closed since it's a duplicate

After looking at a few options, we are currently exploring using [Cypress](https://www.cypress.io/). The main advantages of using cypress is that 1. it's promise based so we don't need to sleep to wait for responses, nice features around debugging, it's faster (doesn't need to spin up a browser for each test), and is less flaky.

Downsides: it runs tests inside the browser so it's harder to communicate with the db. Also currently there's no headless chrome, but it looks like they are working on it. It will currently run headless Electron. There's only support for Chrome and Electron, but this isn't a problem for us as we don't need to test on other platforms. List of trade offs [here](https://docs.cypress.io/guides/references/trade-offs.html#).

We are still exploring to make sure it will work for a variety of cases but anyone have any major concerns?

> I'd recommend people to not use their distro's stock python to deploy any python service though

Disagree with this :)  The Wikimedia foundation has strict rules about where we get production packages from for security reasons. We've decide to trust Debian and to default to using their packages  when available.

I'd be totally fine with dropping Python 2 support, but please keep this to Python >= 3.5!

One reason to consider not caching `no data` is that on errors in explore we don't show the button to force refresh the cache. So if it is a transient issue, there's no clear way in the UI to update the chart. Alternatively we could always show the force refresh button if the data is cached (regardless of if it was an error).
